awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Professor Kevin Moeller of the Department of Chemistry at Washington University in St. Louis to use electrochemical methods to probe the highly reactive intermediates central to synthetic reactions that increase the functionality of organic molecules. The effort serves to build a foundation for the design of new, more efficient synthetic routes to molecules of interest to the pharmaceutical and chemical industries and to develop electrochemistry as a sustainable tool for accomplishing those transformations. The broader impacts of the work are both scientific and educational.  On the science front, this project illustrates for others the overall utility of electrochemistry as a sustainable technique. The reactions can be run in a manner that uses sunlight (or any other clean source of electricity) as the only source of energy and generates hydrogen gas as the only byproduct. For this reason, scientists from around the world enlist Professor Moeller to aid their own efforts to capitalize on electrochemical methods. On the education front, the project will support the training of young scientists in both chemical and electrochemical techniques, the development of undergraduate laboratory experiments that expose students to their first electrochemical reactions, and the continued implementation of outreach activities that utilize zoo educational programs to teach science to the general public.  

The specific science being pursued in this project capitalizes on a combination of competition studies and cyclic voltammetry to probe the mechanistic underpinnings of new radical cation-triggered cyclizations. The mechanistic insight is used to develop new synthetic methods that demonstrate how to best take advantage of the reactions. Both the mechanistic and synthetic studies benefit greatly from the use of electrochemistry. Electrochemical methods allow for generation of the reactive radical cations from a wide variety of substrates with nearly identical reaction conditions. This enables the Moeller group to make systematic changes to the structure of a radical cation and then probe how those changes alter the chemical reactivity of the intermediate. The same technique is employed to conduct scalable synthetic reactions, an effort that demonstrates the synthetic utility of electrochemistry and one that is expected to generate interest in electrochemical methods by others in the synthetic community.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: From pharmaceuticals, herbicides, pesticides, dyes and food preservatives to materials found in cell phones, tires, and plastics, chemical compounds frequently define our modern lives and the quality of those lives. For this reason, the chemical industry remains one of the largest, most profitable industries in our nation.

While this industry continues to thrive, it is also faced with many challenges. Often, building the molecules and materials needed by society is not a clean process. The chemical reactions utilized produce waste products that can have a strong negative impact on the environment. For this reason, we need to improve the long-term sustainability of the individual chemical tools we employ and the overall efficiency of the strategies in which those tools are used. In this effort, oxidation reactions are key players. Oxidation reactions are the only reactions that we have that allow us to increase the functionality of a molecule. Yet in spite of this critical role they play in almost all synthetic sequences, oxidation reactions are often defined as much by the waste products they produce as they are the synthetic transformations they accomplish.

For this reason, our NSF funded project has been looking at electrochemical oxidation reactions that use electricity to conduct the transformations, avoid the use of chemical oxidants, and channel the required reduction reaction to the formation of benign hydrogen gas. In addition, the reactions reverse the polarity of electron-rich functional groups in ways that make available entirely new avenues for synthesis. However, the reactions proceed through highly reactive intermediates that we frequently know little about. So, how can we take full advantage of these potentially transformative reactions if we do not have a deep understanding of how the intermediates key to their success actually behave? In response to this question, our work over the past budget period has focused on developing that understanding. This work has led us to conclude that electrochemical reactions are frequently governed by steps that occur "downstream" of the initial electron-transfer reaction, and that we can both understand and control those steps by taking advantage of traditional concepts in physical organic chemistry. This insight has allowed us to overcome barriers that were keeping our development of the reactions from reaching its full potential, a change that is now allowing us to explore new applications of the reactions to synthetic challenges that were previously viewed as not possible. This in turn is allowing us to utilize the electrochemical reactions to not only fix specific synthetic steps within a chemical sequence, but also to develop new, more efficient strategies that can dramatically shorten the overall sequence. In addition, we have shown that the benign hydrogen gas byproduct does not have to be thrown away, but instead can be siphoned off for use as a reagent in other reactions. In this way, the use of an electrochemical reaction within an existing or improved synthetic strategy also allows for improvement in the sustainability of a second reaction by eliminating any need to package and transport hydrogen gas.

 Broader Impact: The broader impact of the work conducted has been both scientific and educational. On the scientific front, the work is making electrochemistry more accessible to the larger chemistry community. While electrochemistry is now more than ever being adopted by the larger synthetic community interested in new, more sustainable transformations, synthetic chemists still struggle with how to think about, and hence optimize the transformations. This is particularly true for reactions that directly use the intermediates generated at an electrode surface. In this light, the work being conducted is playing a critical role by defining for the larger community how to think about electrochemical processes. Of course, this knowledge is only useful if we teach it to others. For that reason, we engage in a multi-prong education effort that includes giving seminars and short courses at both academic and industrial institutions and scientific meetings, hosting visiting scientists in our labs so that they can learn electrochemical techniques, answering questions on the phone and in person about electrochemical methods, and developing lab experiments that can be taught to younger students so that they have a familiarity with electrochemistry. 

In addition to these efforts, we have been engaging younger children in hands-on experiments focused on nurturing in them a fascination with all aspects of science. Much of this effort has focused on developing curriculum for students who obtain their science education in non-traditional environments like home-school programs run by zoos and science centers. These lessons focus on chemical concepts ranging from polymers to electron-transfer, sunlight, and energy, to DNA and how it codes for diversity, to basic concepts in synthesis.


Last Modified: 09/12/2019
Modified by: Kevin D Moeller
